paragraphs.text: Great work as always and great write up on Happ, you nailed him perfectly. Second in the Big Ten in steals per game and third in rebounds per game is a combination you don’t see often.

paragraphs.text: By the way, I’m a Badger fan and I fully concede Swanigan is the best player in the Big Ten this year and deserves POY over Happ. I’ll settle for top 10 in the country.

paragraphs.name: 4af0
paragraphs.text: SLU Alum here. Apparently the driver had a box of wine with her under the seat. She also was still in the bus at the arena when a manager went outside to pick up pizza with about 8min left in the game. She was also supposedly driving erratically on the way to the game. So it looks like she had been drinking pre-pick up and then nursing the box of wine while the game was going on.

paragraphs.text: (Badger fan from Wisconsin) Some interesting notes on Happ since this article: In the last two games coaches have sent the immediate double team the second he catches the ball in the post. It’s flustered him and caused turnovers including an OT win and a home loss to Northwestern.

7323afbe6a5b.title: College Basketball Power Rankings: Oregon Let UCLA Off the Hook

content.subtitle: The Ducks had UCLA right where they wanted, but couldn’t finish the job. Can they win outside of Eugene come March?
content.metaDescription: Oregon had UCLA right where it wanted, but couldn’t finish the job. Can the Ducks win outside Eugene in March? Plus, breaking down Ethan Happ and more in Titus’s Top 12 NCAA Power Rankings.

paragraphs.name: 8c31
paragraphs.text: And for the first 13:30 of the game, that’s what Oregon did. The Ducks picked up right where they left off against Arizona, bursting out to a 37–18 lead. UCLA’s historically great offense was visibly frustrated, Lonzo Ball was a borderline liability, and the Ducks got any shot they wanted. All signs pointed to another massacre until Ball was subbed out late in the first half and UCLA went on a 14–0 run to cut the lead to five. But even then, Oregon stopped the bleeding, built a 15-point second-half lead, and seemed to be in control. Only … well … I’ll let Dennis Green explain what happened next.
